div1.p: IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of MAC FOCK, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
AFFIDAVIT OF MAC FOCK.
Exhibit A.
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON } ss.
MAC FOCK, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says

I. That affiant belongs to the Mongolian race, being a Chinaman; that he believes that the Judge before whom the application for a writ of habeas corpus, to-wit: Judge Cushman, of the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, has a personal prejudice against him by virtue of the race to which be belongs.

II. That he is informed and believes, and so states the fact to be, that Judge Cushman for many was a prosecutor in the United States District Attorney's office for the Western District of Washington, and an assistant solicitor of the United States Government, and in such position formed a habit of thought and belief and prejudice that the United States of America, through its delegated official life in Washington, was in the right in adminstrative matters under the Chinese laws of the United States, and by which official experience, became, and has become, and now is, so impressed with the presumption of guilt of the ordinary Chinese character, under the Chinese Exclusion Acts that although honest in his intention to be fair, it is impossible by virtue of past experience so to do, and he does not and will not in the action at bar bring to the determination of the issues herein, that equipose of judgment essential for the trial of cases in such case made and provided.
III. That affiant is informed and believes and so states the

fact to be, that when the application for a writ of habeas corpus in the above cause was presented to his Honor, Judge Cushman, and that certified judgment upon which the discharge of this affiant was predicated, namely, the discharge under what is known as the McKettrick certificates in the Federal Government, his Honor, Judge Cushman, smiled, and indicated to the Counsel of his affiant that it would take very strong evidence to remove from his mind the presumpton that a discharge under such a certified copy was not tinctured with fraud, showing then and there that he did not, under and by virtue of the Constitution of the United States and the traditions both of the common and statutory law thereof, give the presumption of innocence to this affiant.

IV. That this affiant has not been bale to file this affidavit of bias and prejudice against his Honor, Judge Cushman, sitting in and for the Western District of Washington, ten days before the beginning of the term of this court, for the reason that affiant had no knowledge or information that it would be necessary to bring a writ of habeas corpus until the 4th day of June A.D. 1913, and therefore, he was not able to comply with the statute in such case made and provided, to-wit, the filing of such affidavit of bias and prejudice as herein set forth, within the ten days, as required by statute.

V. That he was not aware of the bias and prejudice of Judge Cushman in asking for the writ of habeas corpus herein, and did not fully consider the same until informed by his Counsel of the remarks of Judge Cushman upon the granting of said writ, when the mattes and things herein set forth are called to his attention, and he then stated, and now believes and is informed by his Counsel that he cannot have a fair and impartial trial before his Honor, Judge Cushman, sitting as a United States District Judge within and for the Western District of Washington, because of the facts aforesaid, and because of the tempermental attitude of the mind of said Judge Cushman, by virtue of being a Governmental
employee for so many years, seeking the deportation of the Chinese race in general.

VI. That he has stated fully and fairly to his Counsel, L. Frank Brown and Victor M. Place, the matters and thiings herein set forth, and they in good faith believe, as he is informed and believes, that such application for the calling in of another Judge, according to the statues of the United States of America, (36 Statue at large, Section 1090), should prevail, and that his Honor, Judge Cushman, as aforesaid, should proceed no further therein, but another Judge from the interior portions of the country who has no such bias or prejudice against the Mongolian race in general, or any person seeking entrance therein under and by virtue of the McKettrick discharges known to the Government, might be chosen to sit fairly and impartially upon the issue involved against this affiant.

WHEREFORE, affiant prays that his honor, Judge Cushman, shall proceed no further herein, and that his Honor, Judge Rudkin, of the Northern District of Washington, shall be chosen to proceed herein, or some other judge who has not the tempermental attitude fo his Honor, Judge Cushman, as herein set forth.
Witness
(Mac Fock)
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 21st day of June, A.D. 1913.
Benjamin M. Leowiz
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
